text: if you tell somebody you're a cook or a
chef they have an idea what it is that
you do everybody has tried and has
succeeded or tried and failed to cook an
egg or he's got a range in a frying pan
but if you tell somebody you're a baker
they get kind of wide-eyed you're
dealing with something that in three
hours is going to either be a beautiful
loaf of bread or not
I'm Austin hall I'm the head Baker at
she-wolf bakery in Long Island City that
was in Roma's kitchen for two years in
January last year we shifted our
operations to this commissary kitchen in
Long Island City
I think about it as like a nurturing
like a farming like a shepherding you're
trying to take these organisms and like
help them to be the best loaf of bread
they can be when people think about
cooking and like building recipes
they're thinking about like bending the
ingredients to their vision for me
baking is more about nurturing those
ingredients along
it's funny how little baking can be
about taste
once you set a recipe right you kind of
have an idea what it tastes like and
then every time you do that recipe after
that it's a matter of managing logistics
we have been working with pharma ground
flower for a long time the Miche is 100%
New York State grain I think that's part
of what is really important about the
local farm kind of movement with you
know the people behind what you're
serving and they know you I think
there's a weird line that happens in a
bakery where you move from being a
bakery with a log with people you have a
lot of skills to a bakery that has a lot
of machines and I don't know where that
limit ends where you can stop
considering yourself to be I really
don't use it with our technologists it
doesn't mean anything anymore but a
bakery where there are people using
skills rather than people using machines
they come out better when you do them by
hand
you
